To identify any early window when it may be possible to assess IOP without an obvious anesthetic effect, 195 mice of strain B6 were anesthetized with the 1X dose and IOP was measured at 1 minute time points between 4 and 12 minutes after administration (Figure 5).

At the 5 minute measurement, however, IOP was the same using all doses suggesting that the anesthetic effect on IOP had not yet occurred.
The same was true for independent cohorts of mice of different ages that were analyzed at different times (Figure 10A).
This was true of most strains assessed on multiple occasions.
It was not possible to analyze all age groups of each strain at the same time in the aging experiments.
It was not possible to analyze all age groups of each strain at the same time in the aging experiments.

The throughput and reproducibility also is sufficient for mutagenesis screens [ 28 29 30 ] . These are important approaches as they may allow the association of genes with IOP and glaucoma whose currently known functions do not suggest that they affect aqueous humor dynamics or do not immediately identify them as likely glaucoma candidates.
At the 5 minute measurement, however, IOP was the same using all doses suggesting that the anesthetic effect on IOP had not yet occurred.

In that study, anesthesia had a minor effect on blood pressure during the first 15 minutes following injection but a strong hypotensive effect between 15 and 30 minutes that continued for more than an hour [ 35 ] . In contrast, intraperitoneally administered ketamine (100 mg/kg) was shown to rapidly decrease IOP in a different rat study [ 36 ] . IOP decreased significantly between a conscious measurement and the first possible measurement under anesthesia (defined as time 0).
In trained hands, our measurement procedure is reliable, accurate and rapid enough to allow large scale genetic studies of factors determining IOP.
In trained hands, our measurement procedure is reliable, accurate and rapid enough to allow large scale genetic studies of factors determining IOP.
If real, this sporadic sex difference was not dependent on age, sometimes occurring in a group of B6 mice at a particular age and sometimes not occurring in a separate group of the same age.

Thus it is feasible to assess sufficient numbers of mice for quantitative trait locus (QTL) analysis methods and to use these methods to identify chromosomal regions contributing to strain differences in IOP.

To test if deficiency of carbonic anhydrase II leads to decreased IOP, we analyzed mice of a B6 background that were genetically similar but with normal or mutant alleles of the Car2 gene [ 25 26 ] . There was no difference in IOP between normal and mutant mice (Figure 9, P = 0.5).
5 mmHg) and demonstrated significant differences in intraocular pressure levels between four mouse strains.

This is in agreement with a number of human studies, which show that IOP is equal between the sexes [ 52 53 ] . However, some studies have found sex-specific differences (typically with higher IOP in females and the magnitude of the difference increasing after 40 years of age) [ 53 54 ] . Of possible relevance, we previously reported that female mice of strains DBA/2J and AKXD-28/Ty develop elevated IOP at an earlier age than males [ 14 19 ] .
The average IOP of different cohorts of strains CBA/CaJ, CBA/CaHN (both high end of spectrum) and B6 were consistent over time.

Some but not all human studies have reported a positive association between IOP and blood pressure [ 48 52 ] . Our comparison of the relationship between blood pressure and IOP in young, adult female mice of different mouse strains, whose blood pressures differed up to 36 mmHg, did not reveal a positive correlation.

All dark period measurements were made between 1 and 3 hours after the lights turned off.

Previously, a rise of IOP was reported to occur before onset of the dark period in rats [ 21 ] , and rats and rabbits were shown to have higher IOP during the dark period compared to the light period [ 21 68 69 ] . Thus, we compared the IOPs of mice at different times of day and identified several strains with significantly higher IOP during the dark compared to the light period.

In support of a later effect of anesthesia (since general anesthesia is reported to mask diurnal variation in IOP [ 21 ] ), we identified increased IOP during the dark compared to the light period of the day in several tested strains (Figure 6).

Previously, a rise of IOP was reported to occur before onset of the dark period in rats [ 21 ] , and rats and rabbits were shown to have higher IOP during the dark period compared to the light period [ 21 68 69 ] . Thus, we compared the IOPs of mice at different times of day and identified several strains with significantly higher IOP during the dark compared to the light period.
In contrast to pigmented B6 mice (Figure 6), the IOPs of the albino B6 mice were not increased at measurement during the dark compared to light period of the day (P = 0.6, Figure 10B).
